description: From Latin extispicium, from extispex (“diviner of entrails”) + -ium (forming abstract nouns).

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Haruspicy: the study and divination by use of animal entrails, usually the victims of sacrifice.
examples: They became experts in what is called extispicy, or the readings of organs of sacrificed animals.

entries.meaning: (countable) A specific instance of such divination.
examples: This image has been interpreted as the performance of “an extispicy on an animal whose flesh the king will later eat."
